title: [BEAM-12830] Replace GoGradle plugin with Shell Scripts.
body:
GoGradle is blocking some log4j fixes and upgrading to Gradle7, so it must be removed. * Adds a central script to manage what Go version we build with. Bootstraps from system go version. * Has the integration/postcommit script use it. * Initial changes to call into script from build.gradle files, and removing gogradle plugin. * Updates the local env script to install the right version of Go. TODO(lostluck) file PR for multi-arching the scripts. This will break the user experience of running Gradle commands in non Linux Amd64 platfoms, but this can be fixed at a later PR. There is likely some way to clean this up better, or pre-handle the Go version downloading script, but this way had fewer changes to start. To be considered in a later PR though. ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! title: [BEAM-13434] Pin transitive log4j dependencies to 2.17.0 in :sdks:java:io:hcatalog and :sdks:java:extensions:sql:hcatalog
body:
Note this doesn't override the transitive dependency, end users can still pull in a vulnerable log4j if they fulfill the provided dependency by adding a hive/hcatalog dependency and they don't pin log4j. This just: 1. Ensures we don't need a vulnerable log4j to build Beam 2. Makes CI verify the artifacts will work with a newer log4j Tested locally with unit tests, and confirmed that all log4j 2 dependencies are force upgraded via the dependency report: ``` grep -rnw title: [BEAM-13494] Avoid draining Kinesis API limits & CPU when reading from empty or low throughput shard
body:
In case Kinesis reads from a shared with no records available, the read loop repeats unthrottled and exhausts API limits as well as CPU. This sets a default rate limiter that uses an exponential backoff in case: - the request was throttled - the response was empty ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! title: [BEAM-13443] Avoid blocking put to Kinesis records queue to shutdown readers faster
body:
Using `put` on bounded blocking queues is a rather bad practice as it blocks for an unlimited period of time if the capacity is exhausted. Especially when using KPL aggregated records this can easily happen. As a results threads need to be interrupted when forcefully shutting down the reader pool. This seems to mostly be an issue when using the direct runner as it frequently closes the reader. ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! title: [BEAM-8388] Make sdk-java-core compatible with avro 1.8 & 1.9
body:
Follow up from: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/16080#issuecomment-990888132 Beam can run with different versions of avro at runtime. However, some fixes from avro 1.9 are not visible due to beam internals * [AVRO-1891](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AVRO-1891) is fixed by adding the conversion at compile time in the generated class' model. Beam does not currently read the `SpecificData` form the class. * [BEAM-8329](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8329) ReflectData is not supposed to use the logical conversions by default. Users should either use a `CustomEncoding` with the `AvroEncode` annotation or manually add the conversion to their own `ReflectData` which is not possible everywhere in beam. * [BEAM-9144](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-9144) is a 'snowflake'. All other joda logical time conversions are still failing. (`date`, `time-millis`, `time-micros`, `timestampt-micros`). This should not be in the framework but in the user code This PR aims to * Keep both avro 1.8 and 1.9 support * Use proper logical type conversions when using avro 1.9 specific data (`useReflectApi` must be disabled) * Give users the possibility to provide their own avro data in the `DatumWriterFactory` and `DatumReaderFactory` used by beam internals Needs discussion: * `AvroCoder` should have constructor with `DatumWriterFactory` and `DatumReaderFactory` but this causes a serialization issue with the [`AvroCoderCloudObjectTranslator`](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/runners/google-cloud-dataflow-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/dataflow/util/AvroCoderCloudObjectTranslator.java) whenre the object needs to be converted into a json form. ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! title: Use a patched shadow 6.1.0 plugin using Log4j 2.16.0
body:
Adding a patched and locally build shadow plugin 6.1.0 using Log4j 2.16.0 Changes to the shadow plugin is based on: https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow/commit/402c14fab1fb241c82898082e7ca58417c75c6f6 Steps used to build: 1. git checkout tags/6.1.0 -b 6.1.0 2. apply the patch from above: ``` diff --git a/gradle/dependencies.gradle b/gradle/dependencies.gradle index 59d8519..9b27380 100644 --- a/gradle/dependencies.gradle +++ b/gradle/dependencies.gradle @@ -10,7 +10,7 @@ dependencies { implementation 'commons-io:commons-io:2.5' implementation 'org.apache.ant:ant:1.9.7' implementation 'org.codehaus.plexus:plexus-utils:3.0.24' - implementation "org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core:2.13.3" + implementation "org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-core:2.16.0" implementation('org.vafer:jdependency:2.1.1') { exclude group: 'org.ow2.asm' } ``` 3. build: `./gradlew publishToMavenLocal` 4. Copy the resulting jar from : `~/.m2/repository/com/github/jengelman/gradle/plugins/shadow/6.1.0-SNAPSHOT/shadow-6.1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar` ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! title: [BEAM-13015] Add a state backed iterable that can be mutated under certain circumstances.
body:
clearAndAppend is trivial and the existing caching state doesn't matter. append can only be done when the entire iterable is loaded. See https://s.apache.org/beam-fn-state-api-and-bundle-processing#heading=h.tms0ncgbzz6f for more details. title: [BEAM-13271] Bump errorprone to 2.10.0
body:
In preparation for upgrading to errorprone 2.11.0 when it comes out, I went ahead and made the jump from 2.3.4 -> 2.10.0 so we can go ahead and address those issues. This exposed an issue in the new ArgumentSelectionDefectChecker (https://github.com/google/error-prone/issues/2745). I was able to resolve this for some projects by bumping autoservice to 1.0.1 (from 1.0-rc6), but a few projects that have transitive dependencies on old guava versions still run into the issue, so I disabled the check for now. For most of the remaining new checks I've just disabled them (56af3f1d5d7dec51a9ad54ead06677a7f704c679). Others I've gone ahead and addressed. I tried to split out the trivial changes (d5f9a05cbb8594971d7819e348df1589d9b6eee1) from those that are more involved and may require more scrutiny (5de18c7d454c26ad523580b0b14a041b1946a813). `ValidatesRunner` compliance status (on master branch) --------------------------------------------------------

title: [BEAM-13459] Cache artifacts across job runs on python+dataflow
body:
This adds support for caching artifacts across job runs to the python dataflow runner. The method it uses is slightly different than the JVM uses to work around some limitations to the python container boot code. Specifically: - Certain artifacts must have a specific name (dataflow_python_sdk.tar, pipeline.pb, etc) - All artifacts for a job must be in the same "directory" on GCS To work around this, we stage artifacts in a two step process now (gated by a pipeline flag, default value TBD?): - First upload the artifact to a common cache location (`artifact_cache`) directly under the staging directory. In this location the artifact is named using its sha256 hash. If the file already exists, this step is skipped (which is the slowest step) - Once uploaded (either because it was a cache hit, or just uploaded), perform a GCS copy operation to "copy" the file from its cached location into where it should be in the job's unique staging directory. This operation is fast since its a GCS->GCS copy in the same bucket. Ideally we wouldn't need these workarounds, but this works well for now. If the boot code is ever enhanced to fix the above two issues, it'd be easy to change this to use a new caching method. Just choosing some reviewers based on who's last changed code here: R: @ihji @tvalentyn ------------------------ Thank you for your contribution! Follow this checklist to help us incorporate your contribution quickly and easily: - [ ] [**Choose reviewer(s)**](https://beam.apache.org/contribute/#make-your-change) and mention them in a comment (`R: @username`). - [x] Format the pull request title like `[BEAM-XXX] Fixes bug in ApproximateQuantiles`, where you replace `BEAM-XXX` with the appropriate JIRA issue, if applicable. This will automatically link the pull request to the issue. - [ ] Update `CHANGES.md` with noteworthy changes. - [x] If this contribution is large, please file an Apache [Individual Contributor License Agreement](https://www.apache.org/licenses/icla.pdf). title: Updated the base images to use debian:bullseye
body:
Python, Go, Java dockerfiles are updated for Beam Playground to use debian bullseye Python, Gom Java dockerfiles are updated for Beam SDK to use debian bullseye Java dockerfile uses openjdk. openjdk updates the base image on their end.

Even though the default images uses latest distribution(eg: bullseye) of the OS, it's good to have control over the distribution that we use by specifying the distribution name while pulling the image.

------------------------ Thank you for your contribution!
